rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Salix babylonica
rdf:Description.ns2:abstract: Salix babylonica (Babylon willow or weeping willow; Chinese: 垂柳; pinyin: chuí liǔ) is a species of willow native to dry areas of northern China, but cultivated for millennia elsewhere in Asia, being traded along the Silk Road to southwest Asia and Europe.
rdf:Description.ns3:taxonomy:
Salix babylonica was described and named scientifically by Carl Linnaeus in 1736, who knew the species as the pendulous-branched ("weeping") variant then recently introduced into the Clifford garden in Hartekamp in The Netherlands .
Salix babylonica Carl Linnaeus Hartekamp The Netherlands
